dcm.util.aclosing(thing)[source]#

Context manager that ensures that an async iterator is closed

See PEP 533 for an explanation on why this is (unfortunately) needed.

Parameters:

thing (AsyncGenerator[Any, None]) –

Return type:

AsyncIterator[AsyncGenerator[Any, None]]

dcm.util.create_thread_task(func, args=None, kwargs=None, loop=None, thread_pool=None, shutdown=None)[source]#

Helper to turn threads into tasks with clean shutdown option

Canceling a thread is not generally possible, so we pass an additional kwarg shutdown to func which will point to an event that can be monitored periodically for shutdown events.

Worker threads are also prone to hiding exceptions, so we automatically add a callback to report exceptions in a timely manner and make sure the shutdown event is set, so any other threads sharing that event will also shutdown.

Parameters:

  • func (Callable[..., Any]) –

  • args (Optional[Iterable[Any]]) –

  • kwargs (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) –

  • loop (Optional[asyncio.AbstractEventLoop]) –

  • thread_pool (Optional[ThreadPoolExecutor]) –

  • shutdown (Optional[threading.Event]) –

Return type:

asyncio.Future[Any]

dcm.util.fstr_eval(f_str, context, raw_string=False)[source]#

Evaluate a string as an f-string literal.

Adapted from: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54700826/how-to-evaluate-a-variable-as-a-python-f-string

Parameters:

  • f_str (str) – The string to interpolate

  • context (Dict[str, Any]) – The variables available when evaluating the string

  • raw_string (bool) – Evaluate as a raw literal (don’t escape ). Defaults to False.

Return type:

str

dcm.util.str_to_tag(in_str)[source]#

Convert string representation to pydicom Tag

The string can be a keyword, or two numbers separated by a comma
